What are Individual Values (IVs)?

All visible values of a Pokemon (what you see - HP, CP, Stardust needed for next level) are calculated from hidden values ( Stamina , Attack , Defence , Level ).

Stamina , Attack , and Defence are each made up of two parts - the fixed base stat for that Pokemon species, and a random IV.

Your Bulbasaur's Stamina is made up of a Bulbasaur's fixed base stamina (90) + a random stamina IV from 0-15.

All Pokemon you catch have fixed base stamina/attack/defence for their species, and also stamina/attack/defence IVs.

 

Why do IVs matter?

IVs are the only thing random about a particular Pokemon.  Without them, all level 15 Bulbasaurs would be the same.  

IVs are what make your Pokemon a unique little snowflake, and determine their genetic potential. 

A Pikachu with IVs of 15/15/15 would thus be the best Pikachu you could ever find, and would have the most HP/CP at a given level that a Pikachu could ever have. 

 

What are levels?

Pokemon all have a hidden level, which is separate from your Trainer level.  Everytime you power up your Pokemon, its level increases by 0.5.  The maximum level a Pokemon can be is your current Trainer level plus 1.5.

The semicircle indicator above your Pokemon in the info screen indicates its level out of your current maximum (the indicator is not linear).

So at Trainer level 10, a level 11.5 Charmander or Blastoise would fill the whole bar, but if you increased your Trainer level to 20, you'd see the indicator move to somewhere in the middle.

 

Does this mean my 15/15/15 Horsea can stomp all over a 0/0/0 Mewtwo?

Mostly, no. Your Pokemon level and species base stats also affect your HP/CP.  Battles also take into account your move power and types.  So while a level 40 Horsea will probably win a level 2 Mewtwo, a level 40 Mewtwo would almost definitely tear it apart. 

 

Why should I care about IVs then?

If you're powering up and evolving your Pokemon, you've definitely caught more than one of that species to get the necessary candies.  With 100 Magikarps, how would you choose which one to keep and invest your hard earned stardust and candies in?  You'd clearly want the one which would make the best level 20 or whatever Gyarados, and that would be the one with the highest IVs (*see question about CP below).

 

Does this mean that my Pokemon with IVs of 2/2/2 is useless?

Of course not!  Pokemon are ?living creatures with feelings too ok, they're all of equal worth (BUT some are more equal than others, and yes, a 15/15/15 level 40 Dragonite is probably going to squash a 0/0/0 level 40 Dragonite mercilessly.)  

Also, most Pokemon aren't at either extreme, so the difference in CP/HP between your 11/10/12 Squirtle and your friend's 7/9/8 Squirtle likely doesn't matter too much.

 

Can you change your IVs?

No, they are set randomly when a Pokemon first spawns.

 

What is IV%?

It's your Pokemon's total IVs out of a total maximum of 15/15/15, and gives you an indication of how "perfect" a specimen it is. 

 

What is CP% and why is it  different from IV%?

CP% is your Pokemon's CP out of the theoretical maximum FOR ITS CURRENT LEVEL (ie a Pokemon with 15/15/15).

When calculating CP, attack is weighted more than stamina or defence.  A Jynx with Sta 0 / Atk 15 / Def 15 would have a higher CP than one of an equal level with Sta 15 / Atk 0 / Def 15, even though both have total IVs of 30 and the same IV%.

On a side note, your HP is purely dependent on your stamina.

 

Which should I look at?

You should probably make sure both are reasonably high.  Actually, CP% and HP% would be a better indicator while ignoring IV%, I'll be adding HP% in the future.

For now, just have a quick look at the possible stamina IVs and make sure they aren't terrible.

What does this app do?

Basically, the main calculator uses the visible values (HP, CP, Stardust needed) and works backwards to generate all the possible combinations of hidden IVs & levels which would produce them.

Ideally, you'd want to narrow down to the one true combination for your Pokemon.

The overlay version uses your Trainer level and the semicircle indicator above the Pokemon to work out the exact Pokemon level, which narrows down the number of possible IV combinations.

 

Why is there a range of levels with the normal calculator?

A given Stardust value spans 4 Pokemon half levels, while the overlay calculator can find the exact level.

 

What are all the other functions for?

By powering up your Pokemon, or evolving it, your HP/CP/Stardust changes, which means another set of possible IV combinations can be calculated.

The combinations which are only found in either the old or new set are clearly not possible, and can be eliminated.

This helps narrow down the possibilities to the leftover combinations which overlap between sets.

Eg, your particular Squirtle has 3 possibilities of :
13/10/15
10/15/5
7/15/15

and after powering up has 3 possibilities of :
13/10/15
7/15/15
10/9/14

clearly, only :
13/10/15
7/15/15

have a chance of being the one real combination, so we have narrowed down the number of possibilities to 2.

We can do this with any number of power ups or evolutions, which would hopefully eventually narrow it down to one possibility.

You can save unlimited snapshots of your Pokemon in a "Pokeball" at different levels of powerups and even after evolution, and they will all be automatically compared for overlaps.

 

Why is there a range for IV% and CP%?

The Squirtle in the example above has three possible combinations which lead to the same HP/CP values, but clearly not all the combinations have the same IV% (total IVs out of 15/15/15), leading to a range of IV% values.

Because the CP% shows your current CP out of the maximum CP for your level for a Pokemon with 15/15/15, a range of possible levels leads to a range of CP%.

Of course, since the overlay gets an exact Pokemon level, the CP% will be exact and there is no range.

(Side note for geeky people : you'd think that knowing your exact Pokemon level and an exact CP% means that this CP% would always hold true, but rounding in the CP formula means that the combinations that all produce a CP of 700 now will not all produce the same CP at level 40, but the variation is minimal)

Calculator gives you an average estimate of the perfection level of your Pokemon’s hidden stats
You can add multiple ’snapshots’ of the SAME Pokemon to one Pokeball after powerups/evolution
More snapshots = more accurate estimate, shown by a decrease in the range of the estimate

1 : OVERLAY BUTTON, ignore for now

2 : POKEBOX BUTTON, takes you to your stored snapshots.

3 : Lets you ADD a snapshot to storage after calculating.

1 : Fill in your Pokemon name, CP, HP, and Stardust needed. Tick the box if you have ever used a power up on your Pokemon. Ignore the Level if you don’t know what it does.

2 : Press CALCULATE! If you’re successful, your Pokemon will appear in the circle above, otherwise an error message will popup.

3 : IV% - average estimated hidden stat total out of a max of 15 stamina/15 attack/15 defence. Below is the range of the estimates, and your Pokemon’s estimated level.

4 : CP% - your CP out of the maximum for your Pokemon level. There will be a range if your Pokemon level can’t be estimated exactly.

5 : MORE INFO BUTTON, takes you to….more info. Swipe to next tutorial page.

1 : Tells you your expected CP at max level and max evolution. Worst is a max level Pokemon with IVs of 0/0/0, Perfect is 15/15/15.

2 : Tells you your predicted HP/CP if you evolve your Pokemon right this moment. Will only see this if you select a single snapshot to view.

3 : Number of possible IV/Level combinations which would produce the exact CP/HP/Stardust you entered.
If you press the ADD BUTTON on the main page, you end up here

1 : Either press the ADD BUTTON on this page to add your snapshot to an entirely new Pokeball, or

2 : Press an existing POKEBALL to explore it.
If you chose to add to a new Pokeball, you’ll see this screen.
Once you’ve confirmed, you can navigate back to your Pokebox to see that a new Pokeball has been created.
If you pressed an existing Pokeball, you’ll see this screen.
Press the ADD BUTTON to add to this Pokeball.\n\nYou should only add snapshots of the SAME POKEMON (after powerups/evolutions).

If you navigate back afterwards, you’ll see :

1 : A new snapshot added.

2 : The number of OVERLAPPING COMBINATIONS (increases accuracy of IV% estimate).
Speaking of the View Pokeball page,
1 : Change your Pokemon’s NICKNAME by clicking here.\n\n2 : Edit your snapshot data by pressing this.
The EDIT SNAPSHOT page is the same as the main screen, just alter your values and press the tick to save.
Long press on a Pokeball/snapshot in the Pokebox or Pokeball view to DELETE.
When browsing your Pokebox/Pokeballs normally, you can also press the ADD BUTTON to add a new Pokeball/snapshot directly without having to start at the main screen.

The special OVERLAY VIEW! A different way of adding Pokemon conveniently while playing Pokemon Go.\n\nPress the BUTTON on the home screen to start the overlay. You may have to grant permissions to draw on your screen.

If you’re familiar with the Facebook chat head at all, the same functionality has been replicated here.\n\nYou can drag the POKEBALL BUTTON all over the screen, and it will stay on top. Pressing it will bring up the overlay.

Make sure the horizontal line is touching the end of the semicircle arc. If you can’t make it align, shoot me an email at pogoiv2016@gmail.com or leave a comment.\n\nPress the CALCULATE BUTTON, and you can access a mini version of the regular app, which allows you to save your Pokemon/snapshots.
You can hold down the POKEBALL BUTTON to make the window transparent so you can see the HP/other stats.
